text: CORY Isaacson, 23, unconventionally good-looking, breezil confident but entirely approachable (almost dishevelled, even) sits shitting on a toilet.

Uh, yeah, definitely. EXT. BRENDAN’S APARTMENT —- BALCONY BRENDAN Ehrlick, 23, conventionally GREAT looking, sharpl dressed, is out on his balcony in West Hollywood, Califor looking out the setting sun.
I need you to come to LA.
Oh yeah?

(deep breath) Cory. I’m gay.

You're gay.

Since like...I met you, what, freshman year-
I- But I didn’t know- So that’s like five- almost six years-—

I- I just- I thought-
Dude, you’re pretty gay-

I- you- are you fucking kidding right now-
This is a big deal!
--.sort of-

What’re you talking about?
Oh my god. Does anyone else know?
...Yes?...Everybody?
What!? HOW!?
You’re not subtle- all you talk about is clothes, and cooking, and you spend more time on your hair than any guy I’ve ever met, gay or straight-
But that’s not-
And you always comment on what women are wearing-—
Lots of men do that-
Yeah but you always do it like, you know, like “I'd like to be wearing that-” Brendan gasps.
You live in West Hollywood, isn’t that like, the gay place-
No but- I didn’t- I didn’t move here because I was gay, I wasn’t gay yet-
You were always gay-
I just moved here because the people looked nice!
Like, yeah, like nice to fuck? Like the men, the gay men looked nice to fuck-
NO! CORY god...DAMN IT!
I’m just glad it’s finally out, really. How did your parents-
It’s not.
What?
It’s not out. I’m not out. Cory leans forward.
Your parents don’t know?

I haven’t told anyone. That’s why I want you to come. The new season of my show starts this Sunday and I want to get it out before that. My parents are in town and I’1l just get it all done, clean sweep, but I need you to be here for...you know, emotional damage control. Cory thinks. A guy in a stall near him moans.
When?
Now. Tonight.
Dude, I can’t- I’m still figuring out my move-
You've been moving for two years Cory. I bought you a ticket. Someone in the stall next to him flushes. BRENDAN (CONT’D) Did someone just flush a toilet?
Yeah, I’m sorry, I’m taking a shit in the bathroom at the IHOP on Florence street.
+..-I love that IHOP. Cory notices the toilet paper is out. He sighs. Cory look around deep in thought. He bites his lip, and then:
I guess I’1l see you tonight.

Yes! I love you Cory! Everything's all in your email alr- Cory hangs up. He slowly pushes open the stall door, and peeks out. The coast is clear. We watch as he makes an awkward hopping run with his pants around his ankles to t stall next to his, and pushes open the door. There’s a man on the toilet. They stare at each other.
I’m not gay. My friend is gay. There’s a long beat.
Gimme all your toilet paper.
A Boeing 757 taking off.

How could you do this to me? I don’t understand! Explain to me, explain to me how you could fucking do this, are you this fucking broken? Are you just a, just a fucking sociopath- I don’t understand, I need you to explain it to me. I’m listening,...Explain it to me. There’s a beat.
Gabbi-
I think you should leave.
You think I should leave? You think I should leave, really?
You know that we’re not exclusive, I don’t feel like I owe you any kind of-
I’m sorry, what.
What?
We're not exclusive?
+. no?

I told you I didn’t- I wasn’t ready for a relationship-

INT. BRENDAN’S APARTMENT Brendan’s apartment is too-clean, decorated with posters throughout Brendan’s career, from age 12 onwards, startin with some atrocious thing called HARDHEART HIGHSCHOOL. Oh hold on whoa, what? I flew out to LA, you're gay. No will she or won't she bullshit, you’re gay-

Griffin, his name is “Griffin.”

-looking at me, and, you know, they talk, everyone in the crew talks, and those bitches all already think I’m gay-

I don’t know , I’ve been- I mean he’s been trying to call me, but I’ve been ignoring him for a week now-

I can’t just walk into a- I can’t just- I had a plan, I have a way I want this to go, first my parents, then the public-
He's right there. Why walk thirty emotional miles or whatever when you can walk one? Or something, some better metaphor-
Cory-  14.

This is what I am, man, I’m now or never. You brought this on yourself. Now do we balls out, back to college, NO FEAR, or do we go home and eat yogurt, man, you have a shitload of yogurt in your fridge and if that’s what you wanna do. (beat) Are you a man, or yogurt?

Lights flash, music blasts, and it’s a great time; fuck i YOU want to be at this club. It’s mostly gay men, but the are some lesbians mixed in. Cory and Brendan are at the crowded bar, Brendan trying t keep, his face low. Cory’s taking a shot, while Brendan ignores his.

It’s so boring back home, man, I never do anything anymore. Like nothing like you wouldn't believe it I don’t do anything, man. He’s not as dreamy as I thought he'd be. I went into this afraid I'd see this guy, and boom, me gay too. Brendan peeks at Griffin, who abruptly is BACKLIT AND STR A POSE. A sexy female voice whispers “Griffin.”
Well I think he’s fantastic.
(tugging Brendan towards Griffin) Then let’s just-

You got it dude. We’ve got all night. Cory grabs one of the little kebab swords from behind the bar, and uses it to snag an olive from the garnish tray. Gabbi and Cory are asleep in the backseat. Gabbi wakes up, startled from a dream, and then turns, looking at Cory, still asleep.  28. She quickly and very visibly goes through a huge range of emotions; regret, relief, excitement, terror, and finally calm.

Brendan sits in the waiting area of his talent agency. There’s only one other person waiting, an older man. He notices a perky blonde RECEPTIONIST staring at him. He raises his eyebrows: “Yes?” She makes kissie-face, “mwa m mwa,” then bursts into choked silent laughter, muttering just kiddin’, I’m just kiddin’.” Brendan uncomfortably shifts in his seat. Then immediately the silent, self-conscious laughter, and “I'm just kiddin’, I’m just kiddin’.” Brendan sits there horrified.  29.
(all business) Brendan, they’re ready for you.

Brendan is sitting across from STEVE, mid thirties, in a suit, calm and measured, and SCOTTY, twenties, wearing a bright tie and showing a bright attitude, but not actuall very bright. Across from them, is CYNTHIA, early forties, his publicis Brendan looks absolutely miserable.

Turn around. Brendan slowly turns around in his chair, looking out the window. Outside, on two billboards, are huge character on sheets for Brendan’s show, HARD TRUTH. “It's personal.”
“It's personal.”
It’s personal.
Perfect.

He walks all the way home from Santa Monica Pier to West Hollywood, following Santa Monica Boulevard. Nearly ten miles.  33. Finally, he’s outside of Brendan’s apartment building. INT. Kris, come on, I- Laura accidentally whips herself in the foot, winces in p holds in a shriek of anger, and then limps over to the do opening it to reveal... Gabbi. LAURA (CONT’D) Hey, where’ve you been, was your phone off-
